review.title: The "handedness" of language: Directional symmetry breaking of sign usage in words
review.abstract: Using large written corpora for many different scripts, we show that the occurrence probability distributions of signs at the left and right ends of words have a distinct heterogeneous nature. Characterizing this asymmetry using quantitative inequality measures, we show that the beginning of a word is less restrictive in sign usage than the end. The asymmetry is also seen in undeciphered inscriptions and we use this to infer the direction of writing which agrees with archaeological evidence. Unlike traditional investigations of phonotactic constraints which focus on language-specific patterns, our study reveals a property valid across languages and writing systems. As both language and writing are unique aspects of our species, this universal signature may reflect an innate feature of the human cognitive phenomenon.

To characterize this asymmetry by means of quantitative inequality measurements, we show that the beginning of a word in sign use is less restrictive than the end. Asymmetry is also seen in undeciphered inscriptions, and we use it to deduce the direction of writing that corresponds to archaeological evidence. Unlike conventional investigations of phonotactic limitations that focus on language-specific patterns, our study reveals a property that applies between languages and writing systems. Since both language and writing are unique aspects of our species, this universal signature can reflect an innate feature of the human cognitive phenomenon.

Thus, if the probability of any character (e.g. the letters "a-z" in the case of the English alphabet) is at the beginning (or end of a word), we will be above the corresponding probability of the index.

sections.heading: Discussion
sections.text: It is one of the basic prerequisites for the interpretation of any linguistic sequence. A variety of possible approaches can be seen in different writing systems, both in history and in the present. However, the most common, left-to-right, horizontal lines of writing are the directions in which all fonts are derived from Greek and Greek, including the fonts of English, French, German, Hindi and Tamil. Scripts written in the other direction, i.e., right-to-left in horizontal lines, are also used in ancient and modern Semitic writing systems, including Arabic and Hebrew. Another common orientation is from top to bottom in vertical columns, which is the direction in which Chinese writings are traditionally written (like Japanese). Other, less frequent, directions of the writing are also known, including the top (the Celtic Ogham script) and boustrophedon, which follows one another in the direction.

sections.heading: Methods
sections.text: We have data from written corpora of twenty-four languages (twenty-two units = 1 x) for nine linguistic families, as well as two linguistic isolates), along with a corpus of undeciphered descriptions from the Indus Valley Civilization (ca. 2600-1900 BCE). The writing systems, which are covered by a variety of sources, range from alphabetical (which use only a few dozen different letters) to syllabic to logographic characters (with thousands of characters).The average corpus size is about ten thousand unique words collected from a variety of sources. Each word considered for our analysis consists of several graphics that correspond to letters, logograms, hieroglyphics or syllables used depending on the writing system used. Detailed description of each corpus is provided in the supplementary information.

sections.heading: Robustness of results
sections.text: An important consideration in quantifying the inequality in the use of characters is the size of the signatures, i.e. the number of visually different characters (sometimes referred to as "graphs") that can be identified in each corpus. In several scripts, these could be considered as separate characters or broken down into the constituent characters, which will result in very different signatures. Semitic scripts such as Arabic and Hebrew, which are essentially consonant alphabets, are either considered as such.
